choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

 

The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways 

 

  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.

 

The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.

 

Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side: Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side: Incorrect for the same reason as above.

 

Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side: Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.

 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili.

 

From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteraemia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and haemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in immunocompromised hosts and those with chronic wounds but not typically presenting with purpuric rash and meningitis.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: A common cause of bacterial meningitis but gram-positive and usually does not present with a purpuric rash.

 

Option D. E.coli: While it can cause meningitis in newborns and the elderly, it is not commonly associated with purpuric rash and gram-negative diplococci presentation in young adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

choices.text: 2-3 hours after a hyperosmolar meal

questions.text: All of the following are true about Delayed or Late Dumping Syndrome, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Late dumping syndrome is a consequence of peptic ulcer surgery characterized by reactive hypoglycemia occurring typically 1-3 hours after meals. It develops when carbohydrate-rich food causes a rapid rise in blood glucose, triggering an excessive insulin response that leads to subsequent hypoglycemia. Diarrhea is typical of early dumping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping occurs in the second hour after meals, typically 1-3 hours post-meal. The timing is correct.

 

Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping is defined as reactive hypoglycemia caused by the carbohydrate load in the small bowel, leading to a rise in plasma glucose, which triggers insulin release and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent - TRUE for late dumping. The symptoms of late dumping include tremor, faintness, prostration, dizziness, and palpitations, which are manifestations of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Late dumping syndrome presents 1-3 hours after meals with hypoglycemic symptoms (tremors, faintness, dizziness) due to reactive hypoglycemia, while diarrhea is characteristic of early dumping syndrome which occurs immediately after meals.

 

 

Features of Early and Late Dumping

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: Which condition is associated with the appearance of Brown sign? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor

 

Explanation: 

 

The Brown sign (also called pulsation sign) is specifically associated with glomus tumors. This sign is characterized by pulsation of the mass in the middle ear that can be observed through the tympanic membrane. Glomus tumors (paragangliomas) are highly vascular neoplasms that originate from paraganglionic tissue. Their vascularity results in visible pulsations that characterize the Brown sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: This is characterized by endolymphatic hydrops with symptoms of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is not associated with any visible pulsating mass or the Brown sign as it affects the inner ear rather than producing a middle ear mass.

 

Option C. Acoustic neuroma: This is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) that typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. It develops in the internal auditory canal or cerebellopontine angle, not in the middle ear, and does not present with visible pulsations or Brown sign.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: This is characterized by abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss. It does not present with a visible pulsating mass or Brown sign. The otoscopic findings in otosclerosis are typically normal or may show a pinkish hue through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brown sign (pulsation sign) refers to visible pulsations of a middle ear mass seen through the tympanic membrane and is pathognomonic for glomus tumors due to their highly vascular nature.

questions.text: Which of the following is disposed in the yellow bag? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood bag

 

Blood bag is disposed in the yellow bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gloves: Red bag.

 


Option C.  Sharps: White container.

 

Option D. Urine bags: Red bag.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: A patient with loin pain underwent retrograde ureter pyelogram to determine the cause of the pain. What is the likely cause of the pain as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydronephrosis

 

The presence of dilated clubbed calyces and a stricture at the left ureteropelvic junction in the given image is indicative of hydronephrosis, which is caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow in the pelvicalyceal system. This condition can arise when there's an obstruction preventing urine from draining out of the kidney and down the ureter. Over time, this causes the kidney to swell and its internal structures, like the calyces, to dilate. Retrograde ureteropyelogram can reveal the classic signs of hydronephrosis such as dilated and clubbed calyces, and any blockage, for instance, at the ureteropelvic junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duplex kidney: A duplex kidney is a congenital anomaly where the kidney has two collecting systems. This means there are two ureters draining a single kidney, although sometimes the two ureters can fuse before entering the bladder. A retrograde ureteropyelogram can identify a duplex system by visualizing the two separate collecting systems and ureters. However, this option isn't the described condition causing the pain based on the information provided.

 

Option C. Renal carcinoma: Patients with renal carcinoma are likely to present with gross hematuria, while pain is late feature. While a retrograde ureteropyelogram can show filling defects, irregularities, or obstructions in the renal collecting system which could be caused by a tumor, it isn't the primary tool used for diagnosing renal carcinoma. Imaging methods like CT scans or MRIs are more commonly used for visualizing renal masses.

 

Option D. Renal stone: Kidney stones (renal calculi) present with flank pain and hematuria. On a retrograde ureteropyelogram, a kidney stone might show up as a filling defect or blockage. The location, size, and shape of the stone can often be identified. However, based on the information provided, the image indicates hydronephrosis and not a stone.

 

Educational Objective:


Hydronephrosis is characterized by the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to an obstruction in urine flow, leading to swelling of the kidney and pain, typically visualized via imaging like a retrograde ureteropyelogram.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

 

The given clinical scenario of rice-water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by the organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

 

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications.

 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea.

 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludes toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

 

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside receptor: Not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While it is a component of cell membranes, it is not the receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Option D. Cerebroganglioside: Also not a receptor for cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that cholera toxin acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors is crucial for grasping the pathophysiological basis of cholera. This interaction triggers a cascade of events leading to the massive, life-threatening secretory diarrhea that characterizes the disease. Proper hydration and antibiotics like erythromycin are key to treatment.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, the land area necessary to implement the controlled tipping using the trench method is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1 acre

 

Controlled tipping or controlled burial is similar in principle to sanitary landfill but at a smaller scale that is appropriate in rural areas. 

 

Trench Method— The waste collection truck deposits its load into the trench where the bulldozer spreads and compacts it. Approximately, 1 acre of land is required for a population of 10000 for a depth of 2 feet and usable for 1-year duration

 

Educational Objective:

 

For implementing controlled tipping using the trench method, 1 acre of land is sufficient for a population of 10,000, considering a depth of 2 feet and a usage duration of one year.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: Which one of these is not used for body fat evaluation? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breslow index 

 

  • The Breslow index is a measurement used specifically in dermatology to determine the depth of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. 
  • It measures the thickness of the tumor and is critical for staging the cancer and determining treatment and prognosis. Therefore, it is not related to the assessment of body fat or overall body composition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Quetelet's index:  This is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is widely used to estimate body fat based on an individual's weight and height. It provides a useful general indicator of health risks associated with body fat levels.
 

Option B. Total body potassium: This measure is used to estimate body cell mass and, indirectly, muscle mass, since potassium is primarily found in muscle tissue. Total body potassium can be an indicator of body composition, including body fat.
 

Option C. Total body water: This is used to assess hydration status and body composition. The amount of water in the body can be indicative of muscle mass (which holds a high water content) compared to fat (which holds less), thus providing insights into body fat levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Breslow index assesses the depth of melanoma skin cancer. It is crucial to recognize that this index serves a specific purpose in clinical dermatology and oncology, unrelated to nutritional or fitness assessments.

 

Obesity indices are –

 

  • Broca’s Index: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) – 100
  • Quetelet’s Index (Body Mass Index /BMI): BMI = Weight (kg) / Height (m)2
  • Corpulence Index (CI) = Actual weight/Desirable weight
  • Ponderal Index (PI)

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke
Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In group 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating whether a correlation exists between CRP values and the likelihood of experiencing myocardial infarction or stroke. The participants in the study were split into five groups and the following table is formed based on the study results. Among the provided options, which statement accurately reflects the connection between CRP levels and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke? [NEET PG 2021]

(CRP à C-reactive protein)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke  

 

The given study results show Relative risk values which are > 1 in majority of the groups.

 

Also, with the increase in CRP levels, relative risk is also showing an uprise. Hence, it can be implied that CRP levels have a positive association with risk of MI/Stroke.

 

Among the given options, the best answer will be option B.

 

 

Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b)]/ c/(c+d)] where,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

 

Explanation:

 

Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenger's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.

 

Option C. Lombard's Test: This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.

 

Option D. Erhardt's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.text: Numerous youngsters from a specific community arrived at a medical facility and were diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control investigation were to be conducted to find the potential association between the chemical waste and ALL, what would serve as the control group? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease

 

Case control study: A study that compares patients who have a disease or outcome of interest (cases) with patients who do not have the disease or outcome (controls), and looks back retrospectively to compare how frequently the exposure to a risk factor is present in each group to determine the relationship between the risk factor and the disease

 

In a case control study, we never try to match the actual risk factor under study

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case-control study investigating the association between chemical waste exposure and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the control group should consist of children coming to the OPD who do not have the disease (ALL). This ensures a proper baseline for comparison to identify potential risk factors associated with the disease.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

 

  • The clinical vignette presented in a patient with difficulty flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, as well as loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • One of the most common causes of humerus fractures is a fall from a great height on an outstretched hand.

 

Musculocutaneous Nerve:

 

It is a branch of the brachial plexus, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in the arm.

 

Muscles Innervated: Supplies the brachialis, biceps brachii, and coracobrachialis muscles.

 

Sensory Distribution: Sends sensory fibers as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, providing sensation to the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm.

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm due to affected biceps. Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and enters the forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Primarily supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and thenar muscles in the hand.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the lateral (radial) three and a half fingers and the corresponding palm area.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of flexion of the wrist, loss of flexion of lateral fingers, and loss of thumb opposition. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve: It also originates from the brachial plexus and travels posteriorly in the arm.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the back of the arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand on the radial side.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Wrist drop" due to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (the "funny bone").

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies many of the small muscles of the hand and some flexors in the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the medial (ulnar) one and a half fingers and the corresponding area of the palm and dorsum.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Claw hand" deformity due to loss of function in the ulnar half of the hand. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: A Gram stain of periorbital exudate in a case of severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis in an elderly diabetic patient reveals irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Apophysomyces sp

 

Explanation:

 

The microscopic finding of irregular, broad, aseptate branching hyphae in a periorbital exudate is characteristic of zygomycosis (mucormycosis/phycomycosis). Zygomycetes (including Apophysomyces species) feature broad, ribbon-like, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae that often show irregular branching. This infection commonly presents as rhinocerebral (rhino-orbito-cerebral) form, affecting the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit, especially in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus as seen in this elderly diabetic patient with panophthalmitis and cellulitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect because Candida appears as oval or spherical budding cells (yeast) with pseudohyphae, not as broad aseptate hyphae. Candida forms are typically Gram-positive yeast cells with or without pseudohyphae.

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species produce narrow (2-10 μm), septate, hyaline hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles. The hyphae described in the question are aseptate, not the septate hyphae characteristic of Aspergillus.

 

Option C. Penicillium: Incorrect because Penicillium, like Aspergillus, produces septate hyphae, not the aseptate hyphae seen in this case. Penicillium has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores resembling a brush.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rhinocerebral zygomycosis (mucormycosis) is a life-threatening opportunistic infection that typically presents with broad, aseptate hyphae on microscopic examination and has a strong association with diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis. Rapid diagnosis and treatment are essential due to its high mortality rate.

choices.text: Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 90% ionized and 10% non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 75% ionized and 25 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 25% ionized and 75 % non-ionized

questions.text: When the pH = pKa of a drug, which of the following statements is true? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized

 

As per the Henderson Hasselbach equation:

 

pH = pKa + log (Ionized form/Non-ionized form)

 

pKa of a drug is the pH at which 50% of the drug is ionized and 50% of the drug is non-ionized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the pH of the environment is equal to the pKa of the drug, the drug exists in a state where 50% is ionized and 50% is non-ionized. This is a critical concept in understanding drug solubility and absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

choices.text: It is caused by Burkholderia mallei.
It is endemic to Southeast Asia.
It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis.
The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning Melioidosis is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (It is caused by Burkholderia mallei).

 

Explanation:

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, not Burkholderia mallei. B. pseudomallei is a saprophyte found in soil and water in endemic regions. It causes a disease called melioidosis which has been nicknamed the "Vietnam time-bomb disease" due to its ability to remain latent for many years before activating. B. mallei, on the other hand, is a strictly zoonotic pathogen that causes glanders and farcy in horses and other equids.

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is endemic to Southeast Asia - This statement is true. Melioidosis is endemic to Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore and northern Australia. The bacterium B. pseudomallei is found in soil and water in these regions, where environmental conditions favor its survival.

 

Option C. It can present similarly to Pulmonary Tuberculosis - This statement is true. One of the clinical presentations of melioidosis is sub-acute pulmonary infection that can range from mild bronchitis to severe tuberculosis-like pneumonia. This tuberculosis-like presentation is one reason why melioidosis is often called "the great mimicker" in endemic regions.

Option D. The bacterium is considered a potential biowarfare agent - This statement is true. B. pseudomallei is classified as a potential agent of biological warfare due to its environmental persistence, relatively low infectious dose when aerosolized, resistance to many common antibiotics, and the serious nature of the disease it causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei (not B. mallei), can present with a variety of clinical manifestations from acute septicemia to chronic suppurative infections, and requires prolonged antibiotic therapy typically consisting of an intensive phase with ceftazidime or a carbapenem followed by an extended eradication phase with oral antibiotics.

questions.text: Glucocorticoids decrease the number of circulating: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Eosinophils

 

Explanation: 

 

Glucocorticoids cause a significant decrease in the number of circulating eosinophils by increasing their sequestration in the spleen and lungs. This effect is a fundamental immunological action of glucocorticoids, with eosinophil counts typically dropping from around 275 to 50 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Neutrophils - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids actually increase the number of neutrophils in circulation. Neutrophil counts typically rise from approximately 4,000 to 10,000 cells/μL with cortisol treatment.
  • Option C. Platelets - This is incorrect as glucocorticoids increase rather than decrease platelet counts. Glucocorticoids lower the number of basophils in the circulation while increasing the number of neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells.
  • Option D. Red Blood Cells - This is incorrect because glucocorticoids increase the number of red blood cells in circulation, not decrease them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Glucocorticoids have diverse effects on blood cell populations, causing a reduction in eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes while increasing neutrophils, platelets, and red blood cells through mechanisms involving altered cellular distribution and production.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

 

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - These act in the proximal tubule. Acetazolamide is a commonly used carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics- Collecting duct: These work primarily in the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the collecting duct. Mannitol is a common example.

 

Option C. Thiazides-Loop of Henle: These primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide is a typical example.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists- early Distal tubules: These work in the collecting ducts and late distal tubules. Spironolactone is a well-known aldosterone antagonist.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

questions.text: The green-shaded region in the coronal section of the brain corresponds to which type of fibers? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of special visceral afferent column except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column. Special visceral afferent refers to sensory information associated with taste and smell.

 

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit's superior oblique muscle.

 

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • Sensory Component: The facial nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via the chorda tympani branch).
  • Motor Component: The facial nerve also contains motor fibers responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):

 

  • Sensory Component: The vagus nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the epiglottis and the root of the tongue.
  • Motor Component: The vagus nerve has a wide range of motor functions, including control of the muscles involved in swallowing and vocalization, as well as autonomic functions.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX):

 

  • Sensory Component: The glossopharyngeal nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and sensory input from the oropharynx.
  • Motor Component: It also has motor functions, including control of certain muscles involved in swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception.
Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills.
Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination.
Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

 

Explanation:


Cochlear implants do not increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation. In fact, the opposite is true - cochlear implants often help reduce tinnitus in most patients who experience it prior to implantation. The electrical stimulation provided by the implant can mask or suppress the tinnitus sensation. Studies show that cochlear implantation can reduce or even eliminate pre-existing tinnitus in approximately 70-80% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception: This statement is true. Cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing for improved detection and discrimination of sounds. This leads to enhanced speech perception and better understanding of environmental sounds.

 

Option B. Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills: This statement is true, especially for children who receive implants early. Early implantation (before 6 years of age in pre-lingual deaf children) allows for better development of auditory pathways and improved chances of developing age-appropriate speech and language skills.

 

Option C. Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination: This statement is true. Cochlear implants help improve sound discrimination abilities, allowing recipients to better distinguish between different sounds. Bilateral implantation particularly improves sound localization abilities by providing binaural cues necessary for spatial hearing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Contrary to increasing tinnitus, cochlear implants typically reduce or suppress pre-existing tinnitus in most patients due to the masking effect of electrical stimulation and reorganization of central auditory pathways following implantation.

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is used for skewed distributions 

 

  • Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand.
