They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.
  • Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Wallis test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test:  Is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C. It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution: Is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D. It cannot be used for small sample sizes: Is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levofloxacin

 

Levofloxacin is known for its high bioavailability, approximately 99-100% when administered orally. This means almost all of the administered dose reaches systemic circulation, making it effective for treating a variety of infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin also has good bioavailability, but it is generally lower than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from approximately 70-80%. It is drug of choice for meningococcal meningitis, also effective in enteric fever and anthrax.

 

Option C. Gatifloxacin: The bioavailability of Gatifloxacin varies, but it is generally less than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from around 60-90%. It is a respiratory FQ that causes dysglycemia, therefore has been withdrawn from India.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin has a bioavailability of about 30-40%, which is significantly lower than Levofloxacin. It is mostly used for urinary tract infections because of its lower systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levofloxacin has the highest bioavailability among the listed fluoroquinolones, with nearly 100% of the administered dose reaching systemic circulation. This high bioavailability makes levofloxacin highly effective for a wide range of bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which ion's concentration change has the most significant effect on the excitability of cells through RMP? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. K+

 

Explanation:


Potassium (K+) concentration changes have the most significant impact on cellular excitability. The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradients across the membrane. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, the decreased concentration gradient results in less K+ moving outward, leading to depolarization and increased excitability. Conversely, hypokalemia causes hyperpolarization, moving the membrane potential further from threshold and decreasing excitability.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Na+ - While sodium is essential for action potential generation, changes in external Na+ concentration primarily affect the amplitude of action potentials rather than the resting membrane potential. Na+ has little effect on the baseline excitability of cells.
  • Option c. Cl- - Chloride primarily influences inhibitory post-synaptic potentials through influx causing hyperpolarization. Its concentration changes affect modulation of neuronal responses but don't have the most significant effect on baseline cellular excitability.
  • Option d. Ca+2 - Calcium functions as a membrane stabilizing agent. Hypocalcemia increases excitability by decreasing the depolarization threshold needed to initiate action potentials, while hypercalcemia decreases excitability. However, these effects are not as profound as potassium's direct influence on the resting potential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium concentration directly determines the resting membrane potential, establishing the baseline excitability state of neurons and muscle cells, making K+ the ion whose concentration changes most significantly affect cellular excitability.

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

choices.text: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6
The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease
No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Gamma-Release-Assays for the diagnosis of Tuberculosis is correct? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10

 

Explanation:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold (second generation) assay utilizes two specific antigens - ESAT-6 (Early Secretory Antigenic Target-6) and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein-10) for detecting TB infection. These antigens are present in M. tuberculosis complex but absent in BCG vaccine strains and most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making them more specific for TB detection compared to tuberculin skin tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6 This is incorrect because the first generation QuantiFERON-TB assay used tuberculin PPD (purified protein derivative) as the stimulating antigen, not ESAT-6. This made it less specific than the second generation test.

 

Option C: These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease This is incorrect as IGRAs (Interferon-Gamma Release Assays) including QuantiFERON cannot differentiate between latent TB infection and active TB disease. They only detect immune response to TB antigens, indicating exposure or infection.

 

Option D: No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay This is incorrect because some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (such as M. kansasii, M. marinum, and M. szulgai) also possess genes for ESAT-6 and CFP-10, potentially causing false-positive results in the assay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold assay uses ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens to improve specificity over the first generation test, but still cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form a boundary of the 'Triangle of Doom'? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The "Triangle of Doom" is an important anatomical danger zone encountered during laparoscopic hernia repair. This triangle contains critical structures, including the external iliac vessels that must be avoided during mesh fixation and dissection. This triangle is bounded by the vas deferens medially, the gonadal vessels laterally, and the peritoneal reflection forming the base. The inguinal ligament is not a boundary of this triangle in the laparoscopic perspective.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Vas Deferens - This is an incorrect answer because the vas deferens forms the medial boundary of the Triangle of Doom in laparoscopic hernia repair, creating an essential landmark surgeons must identify to avoid vascular injury.
  • Option B. Gonadal vessels - This is an incorrect answer because the gonadal vessels (testicular or ovarian vessels) form the lateral boundary of the Triangle of Doom, serving as a crucial landmark during laparoscopic hernia procedures.
  • Option C. Peritoneal reflection - This is an incorrect answer because the peritoneal reflection forms the base of the Triangle of Doom in the laparoscopic view, completing the triangular area containing the dangerous external iliac vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the boundaries and contents of the Triangle of Doom is essential for safe laparoscopic hernia repair, as inadvertent dissection or tack placement in this area can result in catastrophic vascular injury.
